/0x22.title: 0x22
/0x22.text:
<u>An ambient music project</u>

[Bandcamp](https://0x22.bandcamp.com)

Since 2015, after bands and instrumental music projects, [I](/karaman-hunor)'ve started composing electronical music. It started with making noises for a progressive metal album, but later I've found long sine waves and fell in love with the ambient / drone sounding.

I'm inspired by feelings and the music of talented musicians like Nils Frahm, Celer or Ólafur Arnalds.

---

<u>Releases</u>

+ [Metaphases](/0x22/metaphases) - 2017 December\
+ [glacio](/0x22/glacio) - 2017 December\
+ [With love from very small places](/0x22/with-love-from-very-small-places) - 2017 November\
+ [It was dawn when the old man died](/0x22/it-was-dawn-when-the-old-man-died) - 2017 October\
+ [Nothingness EP (early works under the moniker Shiip)](https://0x22.bandcamp.com/album/nothingness-ep) - 2017 February
/0x22.name: 0x22

/thanks.title: Thanks!
/thanks.text:
<u>Technologies</u>

- [Enoki](https://enoki.site/), an experimental ~~platform~~ tool for peer-to-peer publishing.
- [Choo](https://choo.io/), a front-end framework that loves you.
- [Inter UI](https://rsms.me/inter), the most legible typeface on computer screens.
- [Beaker Browser](https://beakerbrowser.com/), the web-browser of freedom.
- [Dat Protocol](https://datproject.org/), the hidden force in this _whole_.

---

<u>Shoutouts</u>

[Jon-Kyle](https://jon-kyle.com) ↔ [Devine](https://xxiivv.com) ↔ [Callil](https://callil.com) ↔ [Alex](https://alexsingh.com) ↔ [Edouard](https://edouard.us) ↔ [Fransys](https://frnsys.com)

---

<u>You should check out</u>

[New Computer Working Group](https://new-computers.group), [Peer-to-Peer Day](https://peer-to-peer-web.com), [The Creative Independent](https://thecreativeindependent.com), [LOW←TECH MAGAZINE](https://solar.lowtechmagazine.com), [Are.na](https://are.na)
/thanks.name: thanks

/p2p.title: Peer-to-Peer
/p2p.text:
These are the peer-to-peer projects I was / am working on in chronological order:

1. [ntain](/projects/ntain) ― Peer-to-Peer file sharing site → 2017
2. [orkl](/projects/orkl) ― Super simple peer-to-peer blogging site → 2018
3. [solo](/projects/solo) ― The simplest publication tool → 2018
4. [forkup](/projects/forkup) ― Updater for forked Beaker sites → 2018
5. [ridder](/projects/ridder) ― An RSS reader that you own → 2018
6. [seeder](/projects/seeder) ― Plug-and-play Raspberry Pi DAT seeder → 2018

---

If you're new to the peer-to-peer web check out:

1. [What does peer-to-peer mean?](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peer-to-peer)
2. [Peer-to-Peer Day](https://peer-to-peer-web.com)
3. [Beaker Browser](https://beakerbrowser.com)
4. [Guides by NCWG](https://guides.newcomputers.group)
5. [Secrets](https://lhs.nu/archive#dat)

---

Story: 

I've been attracted by the peer-to-peer web from a young age ― before I knew actually exists. I remember standing next to a friend and sending a message to him over the internet (I think it was Facebook), when I realized how wrong it is that this message has to travel thousands of kilometers to arrive to him. 

Since then I was planning and trying to build peer-to-peer networks, but then one day I've found the [Beaker Browser](https://beakerbrowser.com) and [Dat](https://datproject.org).
/p2p.name: p2p

/about.title: About
/about.text:
Hi. I’m a developer, working (mostly) on experimental projects with small footprint to help in the re-decentralizing the web. I'm present on [GitHub](https://github.com/kodedninja), [Are.na](https://are.na/hunor-karaman). [Mastodon](https://sunbeam.city/@kodedninja) and [VSCO](https://vsco.co/karamanhunor).
You can contact me via [email](mailto:hunix94@gmail.com). --- **Currently:** - Developer at [GeoGebra](https://geogebra.org) - Experimenting with [peer-to-peer tools](/p2p) --- **Previously:** - Co-Made [Pictogon](https://pictogon.com) --- *"I really enjoy making tools." - Callil Capuozzo* Hunor Karaman, a peer.
/about.name: about

/blog/keeping-sites-alive.title: Seeder ― keeping sites alive on dat://
/blog/keeping-sites-alive.excerpt: There are 2 problems with the availability of sites on the dat:// protocol: 1.) if you turn off your computer and nobody's seeding it, it'll be unaccessible 2.) if everyone solves this with a seeding service (Hashbase) the whole network will start to become more centralized.
/blog/keeping-sites-alive.name: keeping-sites-alive

/blog/ridder.title: Ridder ― taking back control with RSS
/blog/ridder.excerpt: Ridder was made to make content reading transparent and controllable.
/blog/ridder.text:
It's an RSS reader completely owned and run by you, there's no server in the cloud to connect to.

There's no middleman to filter or track what you read.
/blog/ridder.name: ridder

/blog/pictogon.title: Redefining image maps
/blog/pictogon.excerpt: Once upon a time images appeared on websites with interactive areas inside. They were called _image maps_.
/blog/pictogon.text:
"In HTML and XHTML, an image map is a list of coordinates relating to a specific image, created in order to hyperlink areas of the image to different destinations (as opposed to a normal image link, in which the entire area of the image links to a single destination)." ― [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image_map)

I think image maps actualized a desire many of us have: to make something eternally static (object, image) interactive and alive. Sadly, they didn't spread out on the web and searching for clickable areas on an image isn't a habbit. The reason behind these might be the timing and the tools of the age. If you check the ["Creation and use section"](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image_map#Creation_and_use) of the Wikipedia article, you'll see that the recommended programs for image map creation are Dreamweaver, KDE and GIMP (with a plugin). Tools that aren't used anymore or took a turn in an other direction.

During the summer of 2017, together with my friend and mentor [Csaba](https://codecanyon.net/user/sekler) we've created [Pictogon](https://pictogon.com) ― a modern image map editor.

![A screenshot of the Pictogon interface](/content/blog/pictogon/Pictogon.png)

It was fun not only because we built a finished product from scratch in a relatively short period of time, but also because it was the first larger-scale project I've worked on (as for most 18 years olds). As it was just a secondary project for Csaba, I designed the whole infrastructure, built the backend and a part of the front-end, while he designed and coordinated everything with precision. I even built a working recurring billing system!

We tried to keep everything as simple as possible. An image map editor shouldn't be complicated anyways. You have an image → draw some polygons on it → set their content → save → get the embed code or download → put it onto your website.

We've also experimented with alternative solutions for the upcoming problems (some of them worked out, some of the didn't). For example we didn't want to spend energy, money and computing power on hosting images. They're large and there are enough hosting services on the web (most users have a website with its own storage, why would they also pay for storing images somewhere else?). So you can only input the URL of an image as a starting point. Pictogon will never store the file, it's just a middle layer, between an image and the frontend, that turns the former into an interactive object.

We decided to let users download the result and handle the embedding part by themselves. **It's a tool, not a platform.**

We've released Pictogon (into the wild) on 5. October via [Product Hunt](https://www.producthunt.com/posts/pictogon) (which is the only marketing we've done) and luckily people liked it. So much that it became "Product of the Day" and "#3 Product of the Week".

<u>Technical details</u>

The image maps are `<svg>` elements with the image, a bunch of polygons and a script inside.

The frontend was built with [jQuery](https://jquery.com) (I know, it wasn't my decision), the editor was built by us from the ground up. The backend is vanilla PHP.

---

<u>Update</u> 

As of today ― November 02, 2018 ― Pictogon is a settling puddle in our hearts. After its successful launch we were motivated for a few months, but we've started to neglect and don't care. Maybe, it wasn't fully finished at the release and we were tired of it to finish afterwards. I also started digging into building for the peer-to-peer web around that time (and haven't stopped since then). I love this product and hope that someday I can, maybe, rebuild it and relaunch it. Pictogon 2.0, sometime, maybe.
/blog/pictogon.name: pictogon

/blog/ntain.title: ntain ― a peer-to-peer file sharing site
/blog/ntain.excerpt: My first try at building a peer-to-peer application based on [Beaker Browser](https://beakerbrowser.com) ― a retrospection.
/blog/ntain.text:
_This entry was written one year after the events, as it's a very important period and I missed it from my timeline._

One night I've found many #rotonde tweets with beautiful 64 characters long URL-ish texts in my feed. A few minutes later I've found out that it's a little, "underground" social-network. It was peer-to-peer, something I've been interested in for a while, so I've downloaded [Beaker Browser](https://beakerbrowser.com) in an instant and made my profile. It was a slightly abstract way of joining a social-network, love at first sight.

And then there were features to build, bugs to fix ― so I've cloned the [repo on GitHub](https://github.com/rotonde) and started contributing. They weren't important, core features, just little "fine-tunes", but they made me feel happy and curious.

_It was the time just before the rise of the peer-to-peer web, there were only a few applications and personal sites started to appear on the **dat://** protocol._

Somehow I've hacked together a little site, using the `DatArchive` API that lets you share files easily and beautifully. Honestly, its design was the reason why I've made it. Basically it's just an interface that renders the content of a directory and an event callback for `ondrop` that "uploads" the file to the archive. The whole thing made with jQuery.

![Screenshot of the interface of ntain](/content/blog/ntain/ntain.png)

But (and this is a very important "but"), it felt like some yet hidden power on the internet. I was there in my room, launching a modern file-sharing application without the need of a server and buying a domain name. Instantly, the feeling of "we're building a new internet, just like in the '90s" rushed through me.

I've shared it on Twitter and people actually liked and used it.

_If ntain were a baby, then everything I've made since then for the peer-to-peer web would be its periods of growing up. It had a determinate role to my current life._

---

[Repository](https://github.com/kodedninja/ntain)

[dat://ntain-kodedninja.hashbase.io](dat://ntain-kodedninja.hashbase.io)
/blog/ntain.name: ntain

/blog/are-you-the-owner.title: Are you the owner?
/blog/are-you-the-owner.excerpt: I wanted to build a peer-to-peer only blog; kind of like the p2p child of Svbtle and Telegra.ph. Fell in love with the idea of a site, which feels the same for the writer and the reader. The only difference is that the writer can change the content and the reader can't. Thanks to Dat, we can easily decide if a computer is the owner or not of a site.
/blog/are-you-the-owner.name: are-you-the-owner

/projects/cereal.title: cereal
/projects/cereal.text:
Cereal is an encryption scheme based on the AES256 symmetric algorithm.\
The keys never leave the two instances and they always change.

[More details](https://github.com/kodedninja/cereal)
/projects/cereal.name: cereal

/projects/odot.title: odot
/projects/odot.text:
odot is a really simple checklist command line tool. It's pretty dumb, but I'll work on it. It makes todoing very comfortable through short commands.

#### Installation: ```npm install -g odotlist```

[Usage documentation](https://github.com/kodedninja/odot/blob/master/README.md)
/projects/odot.name: odot

/projects/bik.title: bik
/projects/bik.description: Tiny library for isolated web components
/projects/bik.text:
I love [choo](https://github.com/choojs/coo), but sometimes it's too much. For example when I want to use a simple component in a static site. I was too lazy to find a module for that so I've built one.

Uses [nanomorph](https://github.com/choojs/nanomorph) under the hood.

<u>installation</u>

`npm i -S bik`

<u>documentation</u>

On Github.
/projects/bik.name: bik

/projects/stacked.title: stacked
/projects/stacked.text:
If you hate using a service that depends on your connectivity for project management ("todo-listing") and you think sticky-notes aren't eco-friendly + too physical, you're like me and you'll like Stacked.

Stacked is a project management tool based on [Beaker Browser](https://beakerbrowser.com) and [DAT](https://datproject.org), meaning that you own all your data and you don't depend on the cloud (which in many cases isn't available).
/projects/stacked.name: stacked

i love winter\

/0x22/glacio.name: glacio

/0x22/it-was-dawn-when-the-old-man-died.title: It was dawn when the old man died
tracks: It was dawn when the old man died I.
It was dawn when the old man died II.
/0x22/it-was-dawn-when-the-old-man-died.text:
[Bandcamp](https://0x22.bandcamp.com/album/it-was-dawn-when-the-old-man-died)

At dawn warmer waves arrive to the surface of Earth. They break up into millions of other waves, then return into the atmosphere. These waves are the reason that life exists on Earth. These waves our the reason why we die.

"It was dawn when the old man died I." presents 3 perspectives of a dawn. Is just a simple dawn the same for a dying man, for a couple or for a child? Is it the same for you and me?

"It was dawn when the old man died II." is an experimental slowed down version of the first track. Doesn't sure which one describes more the concept.
/0x22/it-was-dawn-when-the-old-man-died.name: it-was-dawn-when-the-old-man-died

/0x22/with-love-from-very-small-places.title: With love from very small places
/0x22/with-love-from-very-small-places.text:
[Bandcamp](https://0x22.bandcamp.com/album/with-love-from-very-small-places)

In life sometimes we stuck into small places, places that make us feel closed and paralysed. Will a hand help you out from there?

"With love from very small places" is a concept album, written for my girlfriend for our anniversary. It's a journey to the surface from somewhere below. From a very small place.
/0x22/with-love-from-very-small-places.name: with-love-from-very-small-places

/projects/ntain.title: ntain
/projects/ntain.description: A peer-to-peer file sharing application based on Beaker
/projects/ntain.text:
Ntain was my first try in making a peer-to-peer application based on Beaker Browser. I love it's design, but it misses many functionalities.

You can use it by forking ```dat://ntain-kodedninja.hashbase.io``` in [Beaker](https://beakerbrowser.com).
/projects/ntain.name: ntain

/projects/pictogon.title: Pictogon
/projects/pictogon.text:
Pictogon is a simple solution to make interactive images and embed them into webpages.

I've built the back-end and a part of the front-end editor. It's a small, yet functional tool and building it was an unforgettable experience. You think differently when you write code that thousands of people will use and you must be safe about payments and about a whole infrastructure.

I co-create it with Csaba, the creator of [Mapplic](http://www.mapplic.com), my good friend and mentor.
/projects/pictogon.name: pictogon

/projects/ridder.title: ridder
/projects/ridder.description: An RSS reader that you own
/projects/ridder.text:
Ridder was made to make content reading transparent and controllable. It's an RSS reader completely owned and run by you, there's no server in the cloud to connect to.

There's no middleman to filter or track what you read.

Currently in pre-alpha.
/projects/ridder.name: ridder

/projects/solo.title: solo
/projects/solo.text:
Solo is a publishing tool based on the [Beaker Browser](https://beakerbrowser.com) and the Dat protocol.

The main inspiration was [Telegra.ph](http://telegra.ph). Every entry is under a different Dat URL and there's no index page like on blogs or publishing platforms.

Only *disconnected texts* that centralize in the author's mind.

Solo is a simplified version of [orkl](/projects/orkl).
/projects/solo.name: solo

/projects/orkl.title: orkl
/projects/orkl.text:
I wanted to build a peer-to-peer only blog; kind of like the p2p child of Svbtle and Telegra.ph. Fell in love with the idea of a site, which feels the same for the writer and the reader. The only difference is that the writer can change the content and the reader can't. Thanks to [Dat](https://datproject.org/), we can easily decide if a computer is the owner or not of a site.

orkl is also 100% dynamic, so it's basically just a bunch of ```txt``` files (using [smarkt](https://github.com/jondashkyle/smarkt)) = no site generation or building.

---

<u>Usage</u>

The magic of Beaker Browser is the possibility to fork a site. To get started you can fork any orkl site, but for the sake of simplicity we will use an empty site I've made.

- Download [Beaker Browser](https://beakerbrowser.com)
- Navigate to [dat://orkl-kodedninja.hashbase.io](dat://orkl-kodedninja.hashbase.io)
- Find the "Fork this site" button, click it and fill out with your information
- Navigate to your site
- Edit the site's dat.json, adding `"fallback_page": "index.html"`
- Read the "How to use orkl?" entry
/projects/orkl.name: orkl

/projects/microne.title: MICRONE
/projects/microne.description: A tiny, minimalistic JS music player
/projects/microne.text:
A tiny, minimalistic JS music player. It's around **2 kilobytes** and it's **xx beautiful**.

[See more](https://github.com/kodedninja/microne)
/projects/microne.name: microne

/projects/seeder.title: seeder
/projects/seeder.text:
There are 2 problems with the availability of sites on the **dat://** protocol: 1.) if you turn off your computer and nobody's seeding it, it'll be unaccessible 2.) if everyone solves this with a seeding service ([Hashbase](https://hashbase.io)) the whole network will start to become more centralized.

An alternative is setting up a seeding service for yourself. A [Raspberry Pi](https://raspberrypi.org) runs super power-efficiently and it's powerful enough to seed DAT archives. 

**Seeder** tries to be a plug-and-play, ready-to-use DAT seeder service. With a 1-command installer and frontend designed for non-tech people it's the simplest personal seeding service.

Developed as part of the [New Computer Working Group](https://newcomputers.group).
/projects/seeder.name: seeder
